ANNEXURE A

ADDITIONAL RESOURCE & RESERVE INFORMATION

Additional information for the resource estimation

Diamond drill cores were obtained in the field for both drainable and total porosity. Porosity samples were sealed in plastic tubes and shipped to Core Laboratories in Houston
column50: for analysis. Depth-specific brine samples were collected from the in-situ formation
column51: ahead of the core bit. Four additional methods were used to obtain brine samples. Brine samples used to support the reliability of the depth-specific samples included analyses of brine centrifuged from core samples
column52: brine obtained from low flow sampling of the exploration core holes
column53: brine samples obtained near the end of the pumping tests in the exploration wells
column54: and brine samples obtained during reverse- circulation air drilling. After the samples were sealed on site
column55: they were stored in a cool location
column56: then shipped in sealed containers to the laboratories for analysis.\n\nBorehole and well spacing is in general about 4 km in most areas
column57: and is consistent with guidelines determined by Houston et al.
column58: 2011 for evaluation of brine-based lithium resources in salar-type systems. The drilling density was sufficient to demonstrate a high degree of confidence in the understanding of the location and nature of the aquifer
column59: and brine grade both horizontally and vertically. The Sal de Vida area has been drilled and logged with vertical exploration boreholes and wells.\n\nThe resource was estimated using the polygon method. To estimate total amount of lithium in the brine
column60: the basin was first sectioned into polygons based on the location of exploration drilling. Polygon sizes were variable. Each polygon block contained one diamond drill exploration hole that was analysed for both depth specific brine chemistry and drainable porosity. Boundaries between polygon blocks are generally equidistant from diamond drill holes. For some polygon blocks
column61: outer boundaries are the same as basin boundaries
column62: as discussed above.\n\nWithin each polygon shown on the surface
column63: the subsurface lithologic column was separated into hydrogeologic units. Each unit was assigned a specific thickness based on core descriptions and was given a value for drainable porosity and average lithium content based on laboratory analyses of samples collected during exploration drilling. Correlation between depth and lithium concentration in the brine was observed further increasing confidence in the method. The computed resource for each polygon was the sum of the products of saturated hydrogeologic unit thickness
column65: drainable porosity and lithium content.\n\nA cut-off grade of 500 mg/L of lithium was used. Hydrogeologic units within each polygon with lithium content less than cut-off grade were not included in the lithium resource calculations. The resource computed for each polygon is independent of adjacent polygons
column66:
but adjacent borehole geology was used to confirm stratigraphic continuity of the units surrounding each borehole.

Mining methodology ultimately would be via well pumping in areas identified as favourable for brine extraction. An on-site pilot plant demonstrated the ability to extract the lithium from the brine.

Drilling information from the production well extensions have resulted in the increased depth of the basement model and have increased the volume of the lithium brine hosting aquifer.

Additional information for the reserve estimation

The methodology used to develop the estimated resources
column67: is different to the methodology used to estimate the reserves
column68: but consistent with the informal guidelines for lithium brines developed by Houston et al.
column69: 2012. Their document provides informal guidelines for estimation of Brine Resources and Brine Reserves
column70: and their methodology is consistent with industry standards for characterisation of aquifers and wellfields.\n\nThe document states that key variables
column73: brine behaviour and grade variation over time
column74: etc. and fluid flow simulation models” are considered when estimating the Brine Reserve and determining economic extraction. Given the nature of brine
column75: the same guidelines regarding well spacing and grade cannot be applied as if the deposit was a stationary (i.e. static) orebody. The guidelines regarding lithium brine deposits
column76: as suggested by the Ontario Securities Commission (2011)
column77: were considered acceptable and applied by Montgomery during construction of the groundwater flow model used to estimate the reserve.\n\nWhere previous methods were used to estimate the total amount of brine
column78: and therefore lithium in storage that could be theoretically drained in the entire mining concession
column79: the method used for reserve estimation is completely different and focuses on the potential for retrieval of lithium via wellfield pumping in selected areas where pumping at relatively large abstraction rates have been demonstrated. As the brine is a mobile fluid
column80: it is necessary to use a calibrated numerical groundwater flow model
column82: to project future wellfield production and projected future brine grade.\n\nDue to various levels of uncertainty in conceptualizing any hydrogeological system
column83: all groundwater flow models necessarily incorporate inherent uncertainty. To lessen the effects of uncertainty
column84: good model calibration to observed field conditions is essential for judging confidence in model projections. However
column85: even with reasonable short-term model calibration to 30-day
column86: hydraulic testing of the brine aquifer that was conducted in late 2012 and in 2020
column87: long-term model projections are less certain because of outstanding variables. These variables include locations of aquifer boundaries
column88: lateral continuity of key aquifer zones
column89: presence of fresh and brackish water that have the potential to dilute the brine in the wellfield area
column90: and the uniformity of aquifer parameters within specific aquifer units. Although the numerical model was constructed to be reasonably conservative when data are scarce or assumed (i.e.
column92: there is always a level of uncertainty associated with projections of long-term outcomes. Therefore
column93: it is appropriate to categorize the pumping from the first six years of pumping at each wellfield as a Proven Brine Reserve. Although projections of long-term pumping past the first six years from the wellfields are less certain. There is a reasonable understanding of the hydrogeological system that over the long-term the projected pumped brine can be categorized as a Probable Brine Reserve for the remaining 34 years of pumping at each wellfield.\n\nIt is standard in the industry to recalibrate and update numerical groundwater models after start-up and during operation of the production wellfields. As the wellfields are pumped
column96: and brine chemistry are generated; calibration to these new data will improve the reliability and predictive capabilities of the model. Future probable reserve estimates may also be modified based on production pumping results
column97:
and projections from the recalibrated model may result in confidence category upgrades of Probable Brine Reserves to Proven Brine Reserves.

Statement of Brine Reserves

The groundwater model simulates concentrations of TDS
column98: which are used to derive concentrations of lithium by linear relationships developed for each wellfield. It is assumed that the relationship between TDS and lithium content is constant during 40-year period of brine production from the East and Southwest wellfields. In this manner
column99: the concentrations of lithium on model projections of TDS in the brine produced from pumping wells in each production wellfield are estimated.\n\nUsing the numerical groundwater flow model projections
column100: total lithium to be extracted from the proposed Southwest and East wellfields was calculated for a total period of 40 years
column101: considering the three stages of the project and taking into account that each wellfield will be pumping for 40 years with a gap of two years between wellfields (East
column102: Southwest (South) and Southwest (North)). The model projections used to determine the Brine Reserve that assumed increasing pumping from both wellfields
column103: indicate that the proposed wellfields should be able to produce a reliable quantity of brine at an average annual rate of approximately 10
column104: 000 m3/d (about 116 L/s) in the case of the East wellfield and 18
column105: 000 m3/d in the case of Southwest wellfield (about 208 L/s). The average grade at start-up calculated from the initial model simulations used to estimate the Brine Reserve is expected to be about 810 mg/L of lithium (East wellfield); average final grade after 40 years of pumping is projected to be 778 mg/L of lithium (Southwest wellfield). Depending on how the wellfields are ultimately operated
column106: these rates and grades may be different.\n\nUsing the groundwater model
column107: the average TDS content of brine was estimated for each pumping cycle for each wellfield. After estimating the total lithium content for each time step and summing the amounts of lithium projected to be pumped during those time steps
column108: a total mass of unprocessed lithium to be pumped from the wellfields was estimated.\n\nTotal mass values in 1
column109: 000-kilogram units (tonnes) of lithium were then converted to lithium carbonate equivalent (LCE) units using 5.3228 as the conversion factor. Therefore
column110: the amount of lithium in the brine supplied to the ponds in 40 years of pumping is estimated to be about 2.48 Mt LCE
column111: assuming no losses during processing.\n\nModelling results indicate that during the 40-year pumping period
column112: brine will be diluted by fresh and brackish water
column113: so the pumping rates increase slightly with time
column114: to meet the anticipated LCE tonnes per year for each wellfield.\n\nDuring the evaporation and concentration process of the brines
column115: there will be anticipated losses of lithium. Therefore
column116: because the total amounts provided in Table 13 do not include anticipated loss of lithium due to process losses and leakages
column117:
those values cannot be used for determination of the economic reserve. The amount of recoverable lithium in the brine feed is calculated to be about 68.7% of the total brine supplied to the ponds.
